title: Why does the uncertainty principle have so many different forms? - Quora

response.answer_text: The form you probably know is this: [math] \sigma_x\sigma_p \geq \frac{\hbar}{2}[/math]By definition [math]\hbar = \frac{h}{2\pi}[/math], so the fraction above may also be written as [math] \frac{h}{4\pi} [/math] Actually, this is only one instance of the generalized uncertainty principle, which is given by:[math]\sigma_A^2\sigma_B^2 \geq \left( \frac{\langle [A,B] \rangle}{2i} \right)^2[/math],where A and B are operators corresponding to observables, and [A,B] is the commutator (AB-BA). For position and momentum, this commutator is [math]i\hbar[/math], and so the general principle reduces to the well known specific case.

There is an uncertainty relation between any two quantities that do not commute. Commutation is represented by this expression: [math] [A,B] = AB - BA [/math] where [math]A[/math] and [math]B[/math] are two quantities. If [math] [A,B] = 0 [/math] then we say that "[math] A [/math] and [math] B [/math] commutes". In classical physics, because all quantities are represented by real numbers, [math]AB=BA[/math] hence all quantities commute. In quantum physics quantities are represented by hermitian operators, which can be represented by matrices. [math] [A,B] = AB - BA [/math] is not satisfied by matrices in general hence there are as many uncertainty relations as there are non-commuting hermitian operators.
